ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a much greater understanding of the anthropology of climate change. Coming into the class I was much more focused on what field data and measurements had to say about climate change. Climate change is just as much an issue of behavior, culture, and adaptation as it is the impacts we are starting to see every day.

I have learned the historical and cultural contexts in which different facets cultural perceptions of climate are manifested: from historical extinction events, natural disasters, geoengineering, to environmental determinism. This class help me move beyond the typical science-based notions of climate to see that issues such as polarized views of climate change, moral dilemma of geoengineering among others are not as straight forward and are highly context contingent.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths of the course were the insights and discussions from class. I sometimes was unable to spend enough time on the required readings throughout the week, but did not find my engagement or participation in discussion lacking as a result. Another strength was the straightforwardness of the schedule and syllabus. The class was very organized. 

I think the course could be improved by making students move their seating arrangements two or three times, so that discussions throughout the semester aren't with the same partners every week.

The strength of this course is its attempt to cover as much breadth in thinking about the different facets cultural perceptions of climate are manifested, from historical extinction events, natural disasters, geoengineering, to environmental determinism. Moreover, the lecture helps to tie the readings together that helps to consolidate them together such that they fit into the weekly topic. That being said, the readings each week could sometimes feel unrelated which makes it hard to go deeper, perhaps this could be improved by choosing readings that are more focused on the topic.

Strengths: 
- Clear takeaways and learnings from each reading, a good understanding and explanation of why readings were chosen 
- Each week's theme was clear and readings were able to provide insight into other readings 

Weaknesses: 
- Could have more student discussions about readings

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to humanities majors looking for a clear and understandable segue into climate science and global attitudes surrounding policy and practices.

Yes, the premise and content of this course spurs important reflection and conversations as environmental issues start to become more prominent. This course has the ability to provide an alternative perspective to topics that are less obvious but still important nonetheless, for instant reflecting on what constitute as a natural disaster if it impacts people differently

I would recommend this course to students who have a particular interest in climate narratives and discourse. This course was particularly useful in understanding the ways that climate change discourse has evolved across time and the way it informs current politics.
